segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (Surface)
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (Surface)

segment.source: Walk through the recommended process of how to deploy Windows 10 to your Surface devices with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.
segment.target: Walk through the recommended process of how to deploy Windows 10 to your Surface devices with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.

segment.source: windows 10 surface, automate, customize, mdt
segment.target: windows 10 surface, automate, customize, mdt

segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with Microsoft Deployment Toolkit

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.target: Surface Pro 4

segment.source: Surface Book
segment.target: Surface Book

segment.target: Surface 3

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This article walks you through the recommended process to deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with Microsoft deployment technologies.
segment.target: This article walks you through the recommended process to deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices with Microsoft deployment technologies.

segment.source: The process described in this article yields a complete Windows 10 environment including updated firmware and drivers for your Surface device along with applications like Microsoft Office 365 and the Surface app.
segment.target: The process described in this article yields a complete Windows 10 environment including updated firmware and drivers for your Surface device along with applications like Microsoft Office 365 and the Surface app.

segment.source: When the process is complete, the Surface device will be ready for use by the end user.
segment.target: When the process is complete, the Surface device will be ready for use by the end user.

segment.source: You can customize this process to include your own applications and configuration to meet the needs of your organization.
segment.target: You can customize this process to include your own applications and configuration to meet the needs of your organization.

segment.source: You can also follow the guidance provided in this article to integrate deployment to Surface devices into existing deployment strategies.
segment.target: You can also follow the guidance provided in this article to integrate deployment to Surface devices into existing deployment strategies.

segment.source: By following the procedures in this article, you can create an up-to-date reference image and deploy this image to your Surface devices, a process known as reimaging.
segment.target: By following the procedures in this article, you can create an up-to-date reference image and deploy this image to your Surface devices, a process known as reimaging.

segment.source: Reimaging will erase and overwrite the existing environment on your Surface devices.
segment.target: Reimaging will erase and overwrite the existing environment on your Surface devices.

segment.source: This process allows you to rapidly configure your Surface devices with identical environments that can be configured to precisely fit your organization’s requirements.
segment.target: This process allows you to rapidly configure your Surface devices with identical environments that can be configured to precisely fit your organization’s requirements.

segment.source: An alternative to the reimaging process is an upgrade process.
segment.target: An alternative to the reimaging process is an upgrade process.

segment.source: The upgrade process is non-destructive and instead of erasing the existing environment on your Surface device, it allows you to install Windows 10 while retaining your user data, applications, and settings.
segment.target: The upgrade process is non-destructive and instead of erasing the existing environment on your Surface device, it allows you to install Windows 10 while retaining your user data, applications, and settings.

segment.source: You can read about how to manage and automate the upgrade process of Surface devices to Windows 10 at Upgrade Surface devices to Windows 10 with MDT.
segment.target: You can read about how to manage and automate the upgrade process of Surface devices to Windows 10 at Upgrade Surface devices to Windows 10 with MDT.

segment.source: The goal of the deployment process presented in this article is automation.
segment.target: The goal of the deployment process presented in this article is automation.

segment.source: By leveraging the many technologies and tools available from Microsoft, you can create a process that requires only a single touch on the devices being deployed.
segment.target: By leveraging the many technologies and tools available from Microsoft, you can create a process that requires only a single touch on the devices being deployed.

segment.source: The automation can load the deployment environment; format the device; prepare an updated Windows image with the drivers required for the device; apply that image to the device; configure the Windows environment with licensing, membership in a domain, and user accounts; install applications; apply any Windows updates that were not included in the reference image; and log out.
segment.target: The automation can load the deployment environment; format the device; prepare an updated Windows image with the drivers required for the device; apply that image to the device; configure the Windows environment with licensing, membership in a domain, and user accounts; install applications; apply any Windows updates that were not included in the reference image; and log out.

segment.source: By automating each aspect of the deployment process, you not only greatly decrease the effort involved, but you create a process that can be easily repeated and where human error becomes less of a factor.
segment.target: By automating each aspect of the deployment process, you not only greatly decrease the effort involved, but you create a process that can be easily repeated and where human error becomes less of a factor.

segment.source: Take for example a scenario where you create a reference image for the device manually, but you accidentally install conflicting applications and cause the image to become unstable.
segment.target: Take for example a scenario where you create a reference image for the device manually, but you accidentally install conflicting applications and cause the image to become unstable.

segment.source: In this scenario you have no choice but to begin again the manual process of creating your image.
segment.target: In this scenario you have no choice but to begin again the manual process of creating your image.

segment.source: If in this same scenario you had automated the reference image creation process, you could repair the conflict by simply editing a step in the task sequence and then re-running the task sequence.
segment.target: If in this same scenario you had automated the reference image creation process, you could repair the conflict by simply editing a step in the task sequence and then re-running the task sequence.

segment.source: Deployment tools
segment.target: Deployment tools

segment.source: The deployment process described in this article leverages a number of Microsoft deployment tools and technologies.
segment.target: The deployment process described in this article leverages a number of Microsoft deployment tools and technologies.

segment.source: Some of these tools and technologies are included in Windows client and Windows Server, such as Hyper-V and Windows Deployment Services (WDS), while others are available as free downloads from the Microsoft Download Center.
segment.target: Some of these tools and technologies are included in Windows client and Windows Server, such as Hyper-V and Windows Deployment Services (WDS), while others are available as free downloads from the Microsoft Download Center.

segment.source: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit
segment.target: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit

segment.source: The Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) is the primary component of a Windows deployment.
segment.target: The Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) is the primary component of a Windows deployment.

segment.source: It serves as a unified interface for most of the Microsoft deployment tools and technologies, such as the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM), User State Migration Tool (USMT), and many other tools and technologies.
segment.target: It serves as a unified interface for most of the Microsoft deployment tools and technologies, such as the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK), Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM), User State Migration Tool (USMT), and many other tools and technologies.

segment.source: Each of these is discussed throughout this article.
segment.target: Each of these is discussed throughout this article.

segment.source: The unified interface, called the Deployment Workbench, facilitates automation of the deployment process through a series of stored deployment procedures, known as a task sequence.
segment.target: The unified interface, called the Deployment Workbench, facilitates automation of the deployment process through a series of stored deployment procedures, known as a task sequence.

segment.source: Along with these task sequences and the many scripts and tools that MDT provides, the resources for a Windows deployment (driver files, application installation files, and image files) are stored in a network share known as the deployment share.
segment.target: Along with these task sequences and the many scripts and tools that MDT provides, the resources for a Windows deployment (driver files, application installation files, and image files) are stored in a network share known as the deployment share.

segment.source: You can download and find out more about MDT at Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.
segment.target: You can download and find out more about MDT at Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.

segment.source: Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit
segment.target: Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit

segment.source: Although MDT is the tool you will interact with most during the deployment process, the deployment tools found in the Windows ADK perform most of the deployment tasks during the deployment process.
segment.target: Although MDT is the tool you will interact with most during the deployment process, the deployment tools found in the Windows ADK perform most of the deployment tasks during the deployment process.

segment.source: The resources for deployment are held within the MDT deployment share, but it is the collection of tools included in Windows ADK that access the image files, stage drivers and Windows updates, run the deployment experience, provide instructions to Windows Setup, and back up and restore user data.
segment.target: The resources for deployment are held within the MDT deployment share, but it is the collection of tools included in Windows ADK that access the image files, stage drivers and Windows updates, run the deployment experience, provide instructions to Windows Setup, and back up and restore user data.

segment.source: You can download and find out more about the Windows ADK at Download the Windows ADK.
segment.target: You can download and find out more about the Windows ADK at Download the Windows ADK.

segment.source: Windows 10 installation media
segment.target: Windows 10 installation media

segment.source: Before you can perform a deployment with MDT, you must first supply a set of operating system installation files and an operating system image.
segment.target: Before you can perform a deployment with MDT, you must first supply a set of operating system installation files and an operating system image.

segment.source: These files and image can be found on the physical installation media (DVD) for Windows 10.
segment.target: These files and image can be found on the physical installation media (DVD) for Windows 10.

segment.source: You can also find these files in the disk image (ISO file) for Windows 10, which you can download from the Volume Licensing Service Center (VLSC).
segment.target: You can also find these files in the disk image (ISO file) for Windows 10, which you can download from the Volume Licensing Service Center (VLSC).

segment.source: Note:The installation media generated from the Get Windows 10 page differs from physical media or media downloaded from the VLSC, in that it contains an image file in Electronic Software Download (ESD) format rather than in the Windows Imaging (WIM) format.
segment.target: Note:The installation media generated from the Get Windows 10 page differs from physical media or media downloaded from the VLSC, in that it contains an image file in Electronic Software Download (ESD) format rather than in the Windows Imaging (WIM) format.

segment.source: Installation media with an image file in WIM format is required for use with MDT.
segment.target: Installation media with an image file in WIM format is required for use with MDT.

segment.source: Installation media from the Get Windows 10 page cannot be used for Windows deployment with MDT.
segment.target: Installation media from the Get Windows 10 page cannot be used for Windows deployment with MDT.

segment.source: Windows Server
segment.target: Windows Server

segment.source: Although MDT can be installed on a Windows client, to take full advantage of Windows Deployment Services’ ability to network boot, a full Windows Server environment is recommended.
segment.target: Although MDT can be installed on a Windows client, to take full advantage of Windows Deployment Services’ ability to network boot, a full Windows Server environment is recommended.

segment.source: To provide network boot for UEFI devices like Surface with WDS, you will need Windows Server 2008 R2 or later.
segment.target: To provide network boot for UEFI devices like Surface with WDS, you will need Windows Server 2008 R2 or later.

segment.source: Note:To evaluate the deployment process for Surface devices or to test the deployment process described in this article with the upcoming release of Windows Server 2016, you can download evaluation and preview versions from the TechNet Evaluation Center.
segment.target: Note:To evaluate the deployment process for Surface devices or to test the deployment process described in this article with the upcoming release of Windows Server 2016, you can download evaluation and preview versions from the TechNet Evaluation Center.

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services (WDS) is leveraged to facilitate network boot capabilities provided by the Preboot Execution Environment (PXE) server.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services (WDS) is leveraged to facilitate network boot capabilities provided by the Preboot Execution Environment (PXE) server.

segment.source: The boot media generated by MDT is loaded onto the Surface device simply by pressing Enter at the prompt when the device attempts to boot from the attached network adapter or Surface Dock.
segment.target: The boot media generated by MDT is loaded onto the Surface device simply by pressing Enter at the prompt when the device attempts to boot from the attached network adapter or Surface Dock.

segment.source: Hyper-V virtualization platform
segment.target: Hyper-V virtualization platform

segment.source: The process of creating a reference image should always be performed in a virtual environment.
segment.target: The process of creating a reference image should always be performed in a virtual environment.

segment.source: When you use a virtual machine as the platform to build your reference image, you eliminate the need for installation of additional drivers.
segment.target: When you use a virtual machine as the platform to build your reference image, you eliminate the need for installation of additional drivers.

segment.source: The drivers for a Hyper-V virtual machine are included by default in the factory Windows 10 image.
segment.target: The drivers for a Hyper-V virtual machine are included by default in the factory Windows 10 image.

segment.source: When you avoid the installation of additional drivers – especially complex drivers that include application components like control panel applications – you ensure that the image created by your reference image process will be as universally compatible as possible.
segment.target: When you avoid the installation of additional drivers – especially complex drivers that include application components like control panel applications – you ensure that the image created by your reference image process will be as universally compatible as possible.

segment.source: Note:A Generation 1 virtual machine is recommended for the preparation of a reference image in a Hyper-V virtual environment.
segment.target: Note:A Generation 1 virtual machine is recommended for the preparation of a reference image in a Hyper-V virtual environment.

segment.source: Because customizations are performed by MDT at the time of deployment, the goal of reference image creation is not to perform customization but to increase performance during deployment by reducing the number of actions that need to occur on each deployed device.
segment.target: Because customizations are performed by MDT at the time of deployment, the goal of reference image creation is not to perform customization but to increase performance during deployment by reducing the number of actions that need to occur on each deployed device.

segment.source: The biggest action that can slow down an MDT deployment is the installation of Windows updates.
segment.target: The biggest action that can slow down an MDT deployment is the installation of Windows updates.

segment.source: When MDT performs this step during the deployment process, it downloads the updates on each deployed device and installs them.
segment.target: When MDT performs this step during the deployment process, it downloads the updates on each deployed device and installs them.

segment.source: By installing Windows updates in your reference image, the updates are already installed when the image is deployed to the device and the MDT update process only needs to install updates that are new since the image was created or are applicable to products other than Windows (for example, Microsoft Office updates).
segment.target: By installing Windows updates in your reference image, the updates are already installed when the image is deployed to the device and the MDT update process only needs to install updates that are new since the image was created or are applicable to products other than Windows (for example, Microsoft Office updates).

segment.source: Note:Hyper-V is available not only on Windows Server, but also on Windows clients, including Professional and Enterprise editions of Windows 8, Windows 8.1, and Windows 10.
segment.target: Note:Hyper-V is available not only on Windows Server, but also on Windows clients, including Professional and Enterprise editions of Windows 8, Windows 8.1, and Windows 10.

segment.source: Find out more at Client Hyper-V on Windows 10 and Client Hyper-V on Windows 8 and Windows 8.1 in the TechNet Library.
segment.target: Find out more at Client Hyper-V on Windows 10 and Client Hyper-V on Windows 8 and Windows 8.1 in the TechNet Library.

segment.source: Hyper-V is also available as a standalone product, Microsoft Hyper-V Server, at no cost.
segment.target: Hyper-V is also available as a standalone product, Microsoft Hyper-V Server, at no cost.

segment.source: You can download Microsoft Hyper-V Server 2012 R2 or Microsoft Hyper-V Server 2016 Technical Preview from the TechNet Evaluation Center.
segment.target: You can download Microsoft Hyper-V Server 2012 R2 or Microsoft Hyper-V Server 2016 Technical Preview from the TechNet Evaluation Center.

segment.source: Surface firmware and drivers
segment.target: Surface firmware and drivers

segment.source: For your deployed Windows environment to function correctly on your Surface devices, you will need to install the drivers used by Windows to communicate with the components of your device.
segment.target: For your deployed Windows environment to function correctly on your Surface devices, you will need to install the drivers used by Windows to communicate with the components of your device.

segment.source: These drivers are available for download in the Microsoft Download Center for each Surface device.
segment.target: These drivers are available for download in the Microsoft Download Center for each Surface device.

segment.source: You can find the correct Microsoft Download Center page for your device at Download the latest firmware and drivers for Surface devices.
segment.target: You can find the correct Microsoft Download Center page for your device at Download the latest firmware and drivers for Surface devices.

segment.source: When you browse to the specific Microsoft Download Center page for your device, you will notice that there are two files available for download.
segment.target: When you browse to the specific Microsoft Download Center page for your device, you will notice that there are two files available for download.

segment.source: One file is a Windows Installer (.msi) file.
segment.target: One file is a Windows Installer (.msi) file.

segment.source: This file is used to update drivers on devices that are already running Windows or that have device management solutions.
segment.target: This file is used to update drivers on devices that are already running Windows or that have device management solutions.

segment.source: The other file is an archive (.zip) file.
segment.target: The other file is an archive (.zip) file.

segment.source: This file contains the individual driver files that are used during deployment, or for manual installation with Device Manager.
segment.target: This file contains the individual driver files that are used during deployment, or for manual installation with Device Manager.

segment.source: The file that you will need to download is the .zip archive file.
segment.target: The file that you will need to download is the .zip archive file.

segment.source: You can read more about the difference between the firmware and driver pack file types at Manage Surface driver and firmware updates.
segment.target: You can read more about the difference between the firmware and driver pack file types at Manage Surface driver and firmware updates.

segment.source: In addition to the driver files that help Windows communicate with the hardware components of the Surface device, the .zip file you download will also contain firmware updates.
segment.target: In addition to the driver files that help Windows communicate with the hardware components of the Surface device, the .zip file you download will also contain firmware updates.

segment.source: These firmware updates will update the instructions used by the device hardware to communicate between components and Windows.
segment.target: These firmware updates will update the instructions used by the device hardware to communicate between components and Windows.

segment.source: The firmware of Surface device components is updated by installation of specific driver files and thus is installed along with the other drivers during deployment.
segment.target: The firmware of Surface device components is updated by installation of specific driver files and thus is installed along with the other drivers during deployment.

segment.source: The firmware of an out-of-date Surface device is thus updated when the device reboots during and after the Windows deployment process.
segment.target: The firmware of an out-of-date Surface device is thus updated when the device reboots during and after the Windows deployment process.

segment.source: Note:Beginning in Windows 10, the drivers for Surface devices are included in the Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).
segment.target: Note:Beginning in Windows 10, the drivers for Surface devices are included in the Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).

segment.source: In earlier versions of Windows, specific drivers (like network drivers) had to be imported and configured in MDT for use in WinPE to successfully deploy to Surface devices.
segment.target: In earlier versions of Windows, specific drivers (like network drivers) had to be imported and configured in MDT for use in WinPE to successfully deploy to Surface devices.

segment.source: Application installation files
segment.target: Application installation files

segment.source: In addition to the drivers that are used by Windows to communicate with the Surface device’s hardware and components, you will also need to provide the installation files for any applications that you want to install on your deployed Surface devices.
segment.target: In addition to the drivers that are used by Windows to communicate with the Surface device’s hardware and components, you will also need to provide the installation files for any applications that you want to install on your deployed Surface devices.

segment.source: To automate the deployment of an application, you will also need to determine the command-line instructions for that application to perform a silent installation.
segment.target: To automate the deployment of an application, you will also need to determine the command-line instructions for that application to perform a silent installation.

segment.source: In this article, the Surface app and Microsoft Office 365 will be installed as examples of application installation.
segment.target: In this article, the Surface app and Microsoft Office 365 will be installed as examples of application installation.

segment.source: The application installation process can be used with any application with installation files that can be launched from command line.
segment.target: The application installation process can be used with any application with installation files that can be launched from command line.

segment.source: Note:If the application files for your application are stored on your organization’s network and will be accessible from your Surface devices during the deployment process, you can deploy that application directly from that network location.
segment.target: Note:If the application files for your application are stored on your organization’s network and will be accessible from your Surface devices during the deployment process, you can deploy that application directly from that network location.

segment.source: To use installation files from a network location, use the Install Application Without Source Files or Elsewhere on the Network option in the MDT New Application Wizard, which is described in the Import applications section later in this article.
segment.target: To use installation files from a network location, use the Install Application Without Source Files or Elsewhere on the Network option in the MDT New Application Wizard, which is described in the Import applications section later in this article.

segment.source: Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator
segment.target: Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator

segment.source: If you want to deploy only to Surface devices or you want an accelerated method to perform deployment to Surface devices, you can use the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator to generate an MDT deployment share complete with Surface device drivers, Surface apps, and pre-configured task sequences to create a reference image and perform deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: If you want to deploy only to Surface devices or you want an accelerated method to perform deployment to Surface devices, you can use the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator to generate an MDT deployment share complete with Surface device drivers, Surface apps, and pre-configured task sequences to create a reference image and perform deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator can automatically import boot images into WDS and prepare WDS for network boot (PXE).
segment.target: Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator can automatically import boot images into WDS and prepare WDS for network boot (PXE).

segment.source: You can download the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator from the Surface Tools for IT page in the Microsoft Download Center.
segment.target: You can download the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator from the Surface Tools for IT page in the Microsoft Download Center.

segment.source: Install the deployment tools
segment.target: Install the deployment tools

segment.source: Before you can configure the deployment environment with Windows images, drivers, and applications, you must first install the deployment tools that will be used throughout the deployment process.
segment.target: Before you can configure the deployment environment with Windows images, drivers, and applications, you must first install the deployment tools that will be used throughout the deployment process.

segment.source: The three main tools to be installed are WDS, Windows ADK, and MDT.
segment.target: The three main tools to be installed are WDS, Windows ADK, and MDT.

segment.source: WDS provides the capacity for network boot, Windows ADK provides several deployment tools that perform specific deployment tasks, and MDT provides automation and a central interface from which to manage and control the deployment process.
segment.target: WDS provides the capacity for network boot, Windows ADK provides several deployment tools that perform specific deployment tasks, and MDT provides automation and a central interface from which to manage and control the deployment process.

segment.source: To boot from the network with either your reference virtual machines or your Surface devices, your deployment environment must include a Windows Server environment.
segment.target: To boot from the network with either your reference virtual machines or your Surface devices, your deployment environment must include a Windows Server environment.

segment.source: The Windows Server environment is required to install WDS and the WDS PXE server.
segment.target: The Windows Server environment is required to install WDS and the WDS PXE server.

segment.source: Without PXE support, you will be required to create physical boot media, such as a USB stick to perform your deployment – MDT and Windows ADK will still be required, but Windows Server is not required.
segment.target: Without PXE support, you will be required to create physical boot media, such as a USB stick to perform your deployment – MDT and Windows ADK will still be required, but Windows Server is not required.

segment.source: Both MDT and Windows ADK can be installed on a Windows client and perform a Windows deployment.
segment.target: Both MDT and Windows ADK can be installed on a Windows client and perform a Windows deployment.

segment.source: Note:To download deployment tools directly to Windows Server, you must disable Internet Explorer Enhanced Security Configuration.
segment.target: Note:To download deployment tools directly to Windows Server, you must disable Internet Explorer Enhanced Security Configuration.

segment.source: On Windows Server 2012 R2, this can be performed directly through the Server Manager option on the Local Server tab.
segment.target: On Windows Server 2012 R2, this can be performed directly through the Server Manager option on the Local Server tab.

segment.source: In the Properties section, IE Enhanced Security Configuration can be found on the right side.
segment.target: In the Properties section, IE Enhanced Security Configuration can be found on the right side.

segment.source: You may also need to enable the File Download option for the Internet zone through the Security tab of Internet Options.
segment.target: You may also need to enable the File Download option for the Internet zone through the Security tab of Internet Options.

segment.source: Install Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: Install Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services (WDS) is a Windows Server role.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services (WDS) is a Windows Server role.

segment.source: To add the WDS role to a Windows Server 2012 R2 environment, use the Add Roles and Features Wizard, as shown in Figure 1.
segment.target: To add the WDS role to a Windows Server 2012 R2 environment, use the Add Roles and Features Wizard, as shown in Figure 1.

segment.source: Start the Add Roles and Features Wizard from the Manage button of Server Manager.
segment.target: Start the Add Roles and Features Wizard from the Manage button of Server Manager.

segment.source: Install both the Deployment Server and Transport Server role services.
segment.target: Install both the Deployment Server and Transport Server role services.

segment.source: Install the Windows Deployment Services role
segment.target: Install the Windows Deployment Services role

segment.source: Figure 1.
segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: Install the Windows Deployment Services server role
segment.target: Install the Windows Deployment Services server role

segment.source: After the WDS role is installed, you need to configure WDS.
segment.target: After the WDS role is installed, you need to configure WDS.

segment.source: You can begin the configuration process from the WDS node of Server Manager by right-clicking your server’s name and then clicking Windows Deployment Services Management Console.
segment.target: You can begin the configuration process from the WDS node of Server Manager by right-clicking your server’s name and then clicking Windows Deployment Services Management Console.

segment.source: In the Windows Deployment Services window, expand the Servers node to find your server, right-click your server, and then click Configure in the menu to start the Windows Deployment Services Configuration Wizard, as shown in Figure 2.
segment.target: In the Windows Deployment Services window, expand the Servers node to find your server, right-click your server, and then click Configure in the menu to start the Windows Deployment Services Configuration Wizard, as shown in Figure 2.

segment.source: Configure PXE response for Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: Configure PXE response for Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: Figure 2.
segment.target: Figure 2.

segment.source: Configure PXE response for Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: Configure PXE response for Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: Note:Before you configure WDS make sure you have a local NTFS volume that is not your system drive (C:) available for use with WDS.
segment.target: Note:Before you configure WDS make sure you have a local NTFS volume that is not your system drive (C:) available for use with WDS.

segment.source: This volume is used to store WDS boot images, deployment images, and configuration.
segment.target: This volume is used to store WDS boot images, deployment images, and configuration.

segment.source: Using the Windows Deployment Services Configuration Wizard, configure WDS to fit the needs of your organization.
segment.target: Using the Windows Deployment Services Configuration Wizard, configure WDS to fit the needs of your organization.

segment.source: You can find detailed instructions for the installation and configuration of WDS at Windows Deployment Services Getting Started Guide for Windows Server 2012.
segment.target: You can find detailed instructions for the installation and configuration of WDS at Windows Deployment Services Getting Started Guide for Windows Server 2012.

segment.source: On the PXE Server Initial Settings page, be sure to configure WDS so that it will respond to your Surface devices when they attempt to boot from the network.
segment.target: On the PXE Server Initial Settings page, be sure to configure WDS so that it will respond to your Surface devices when they attempt to boot from the network.

segment.source: If you have already installed WDS or need to change your PXE server response settings, you can do so on the PXE Response tab of the Properties of your server in the Windows Deployment Services Management Console.
segment.target: If you have already installed WDS or need to change your PXE server response settings, you can do so on the PXE Response tab of the Properties of your server in the Windows Deployment Services Management Console.

segment.source: Note:You will add boot images to WDS when you update your boot images in MDT.
segment.target: Note:You will add boot images to WDS when you update your boot images in MDT.

segment.source: You do not need to add boot images or Windows images to WDS when you configure the role.
segment.target: You do not need to add boot images or Windows images to WDS when you configure the role.

segment.source: Install Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit
segment.target: Install Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit

segment.source: To install Windows ADK, run the Adksetup.exe file that you downloaded from Download the Windows ADK.
segment.target: To install Windows ADK, run the Adksetup.exe file that you downloaded from Download the Windows ADK.

segment.source: Windows ADK must be installed before MDT.
segment.target: Windows ADK must be installed before MDT.

segment.source: You should always download and use the most recent version of Windows ADK.
segment.target: You should always download and use the most recent version of Windows ADK.

segment.source: A new version is usually released corresponding with each new version of Windows.
segment.target: A new version is usually released corresponding with each new version of Windows.

segment.source: Note:You can also use the Adksetup.exe file to download the Windows ADK installation files locally for use on other devices.
segment.target: Note:You can also use the Adksetup.exe file to download the Windows ADK installation files locally for use on other devices.

segment.source: When you get to the Select the features you want to install page, you only need to select the Deployment Tools and Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) check boxes to deploy Windows 10 using MDT, as shown in Figure 3.
segment.target: When you get to the Select the features you want to install page, you only need to select the Deployment Tools and Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) check boxes to deploy Windows 10 using MDT, as shown in Figure 3.

segment.source: Install Microsoft Deployment Toolkit
segment.target: Install Microsoft Deployment Toolkit

segment.source: After the Windows ADK installation completes successfully, you can install MDT.
segment.target: After the Windows ADK installation completes successfully, you can install MDT.

segment.source: When you download MDT, ensure that you download the version that matches the architecture of your deployment server environment.
segment.target: When you download MDT, ensure that you download the version that matches the architecture of your deployment server environment.

segment.source: For Windows Server the architecture is 64-bit.
segment.target: For Windows Server the architecture is 64-bit.

segment.source: Download the MDT installation file that ends in x64.
segment.target: Download the MDT installation file that ends in x64.

segment.source: When MDT is installed you can use the default options during the installation wizard, as shown in Figure 4.
segment.target: When MDT is installed you can use the default options during the installation wizard, as shown in Figure 4.

segment.source: MDT installation with default options
segment.target: MDT installation with default options

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Install the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit with default options
segment.target: Install the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit with default options

segment.source: Before you can open the MDT Deployment Workbench, you must enable execution of scripts in PowerShell.
segment.target: Before you can open the MDT Deployment Workbench, you must enable execution of scripts in PowerShell.

segment.source: If you do not do this, the following error message may be displayed: "Initialization Error PowerShell is required to use the Deployment Workbench. Please install PowerShell then relaunch Deployment Workbench."
segment.target: If you do not do this, the following error message may be displayed: "Initialization Error PowerShell is required to use the Deployment Workbench. Please install PowerShell then relaunch Deployment Workbench."

segment.source: To enable the execution of scripts, run the following cmdlet in PowerShell as an Administrator:
segment.target: To enable the execution of scripts, run the following cmdlet in PowerShell as an Administrator:

segment.source: Create a reference image
segment.target: Create a reference image

segment.source: Now that you have installed the required tools, you can begin the first step of customizing your deployment environment to your needs – create a reference image.
segment.target: Now that you have installed the required tools, you can begin the first step of customizing your deployment environment to your needs – create a reference image.

segment.source: Because the reference image should be created in a virtual machine where there is no need for drivers to be installed, and because the reference image will not include applications, you can use the MDT deployment environment almost entirely with default settings.
segment.target: Because the reference image should be created in a virtual machine where there is no need for drivers to be installed, and because the reference image will not include applications, you can use the MDT deployment environment almost entirely with default settings.

segment.source: Create a deployment share
segment.target: Create a deployment share

segment.source: Now that you have the tools installed, the next step is to configure MDT for the creation of a reference image.
segment.target: Now that you have the tools installed, the next step is to configure MDT for the creation of a reference image.

segment.source: Before you can perform the process of creating a reference image, MDT needs to be set up with a repository for scripts, images, and other deployment resources.
segment.target: Before you can perform the process of creating a reference image, MDT needs to be set up with a repository for scripts, images, and other deployment resources.

segment.source: This repository is known as the deployment share.
segment.target: This repository is known as the deployment share.

segment.source: After the deployment share is created, you must supply MDT with a complete set of Windows 10 installation files, the last set of tools required before MDT can perform reference image creation.
segment.target: After the deployment share is created, you must supply MDT with a complete set of Windows 10 installation files, the last set of tools required before MDT can perform reference image creation.

segment.source: To create the deployment share, follow these steps:
segment.target: To create the deployment share, follow these steps:

segment.source: Open the Deployment Workbench from your Start menu or Start screen, as shown in Figure 5.
segment.target: Open the Deployment Workbench from your Start menu or Start screen, as shown in Figure 5.

segment.source: The MDT Deployment Workbench
segment.target: The MDT Deployment Workbench

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: The MDT Deployment Workbench
segment.target: The MDT Deployment Workbench

segment.source: Right-click the Deployment Shares folder, and then click New Deployment Share to start the New Deployment Share Wizard, as shown in Figure 6.
segment.target: Right-click the Deployment Shares folder, and then click New Deployment Share to start the New Deployment Share Wizard, as shown in Figure 6.

segment.source: Summary page of the New Deployment Share Wizard
segment.target: Summary page of the New Deployment Share Wizard

segment.source: Figure 6.
segment.target: Figure 6.

segment.source: The Summary page of the New Deployment Share Wizard
segment.target: The Summary page of the New Deployment Share Wizard

segment.source: Create a new deployment share with New Deployment Share Wizard with the following steps:
segment.target: Create a new deployment share with New Deployment Share Wizard with the following steps:

segment.source: Path – Specify a local folder where the deployment share will reside, and then click Next.
segment.target: Path – Specify a local folder where the deployment share will reside, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note:Like the WDS remote installation folder, it is recommended that you put this folder on an NTFS volume that is not your system volume.
segment.target: Note:Like the WDS remote installation folder, it is recommended that you put this folder on an NTFS volume that is not your system volume.

segment.source: Share – Specify a name for the network share under which the local folder specified on the Path page will be shared, and then click Next.
segment.target: Share – Specify a name for the network share under which the local folder specified on the Path page will be shared, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note:The share name cannot contain spaces.
segment.target: Note:The share name cannot contain spaces.

segment.source: Note:You can use a Dollar Sign () to hide your network share so that it will not be displayed when users browse the available network shares on the server in File Explorer.
segment.target: Note:You can use a Dollar Sign () to hide your network share so that it will not be displayed when users browse the available network shares on the server in File Explorer.

segment.source: Descriptive Name – Enter a descriptive name for the network share (this descriptive name can contain spaces), and then click Next.
segment.target: Descriptive Name – Enter a descriptive name for the network share (this descriptive name can contain spaces), and then click Next.

segment.source: The descriptive name will be the name of the folder as it appears in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: The descriptive name will be the name of the folder as it appears in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Options – You can accept the default options on this page.
segment.target: Options – You can accept the default options on this page.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the deployment share.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the deployment share.

segment.source: Progress – While the deployment share is being created, a progress bar is displayed on this page to indicate the status of the deployment share creation process.
segment.target: Progress – While the deployment share is being created, a progress bar is displayed on this page to indicate the status of the deployment share creation process.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the deployment share creation process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the deployment share creation process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete the New Deployment Share Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete the New Deployment Share Wizard.

segment.source: When the New Deployment Share Wizard is complete, you can expand the Deployment Shares folder to find your newly created deployment share.
segment.target: When the New Deployment Share Wizard is complete, you can expand the Deployment Shares folder to find your newly created deployment share.

segment.source: You can expand your deployment share, where you will find several folders for the resources, scripts, and components of your MDT deployment environment are stored.
segment.target: You can expand your deployment share, where you will find several folders for the resources, scripts, and components of your MDT deployment environment are stored.

segment.source: To secure the deployment share and prevent unauthorized access to the deployment resources, you can create a local user on the deployment share host and configure permissions for that user to have read-only access to the deployment share only.
segment.target: To secure the deployment share and prevent unauthorized access to the deployment resources, you can create a local user on the deployment share host and configure permissions for that user to have read-only access to the deployment share only.

segment.source: It is especially important to secure access to the deployment share if you intend to automate the logon to the deployment share during the deployment boot process.
segment.target: It is especially important to secure access to the deployment share if you intend to automate the logon to the deployment share during the deployment boot process.

segment.source: By automating the logon to the deployment share during the boot of deployment media, the credentials for that logon are stored in plaintext in the bootstrap.ini file on the boot media.
segment.target: By automating the logon to the deployment share during the boot of deployment media, the credentials for that logon are stored in plaintext in the bootstrap.ini file on the boot media.

segment.source: Note:If you intend to capture images (such as the reference image) with this user, the user must also have write permission on the Captures folder in the MDT deployment share.
segment.target: Note:If you intend to capture images (such as the reference image) with this user, the user must also have write permission on the Captures folder in the MDT deployment share.

segment.source: You now have an empty deployment share that is ready for you to add the resources that will be required for reference image creation and deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: You now have an empty deployment share that is ready for you to add the resources that will be required for reference image creation and deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: Import Windows installation files
segment.target: Import Windows installation files

segment.source: The first resources that are required to perform a deployment of Windows are the installation files from Windows 10 installation media.
segment.target: The first resources that are required to perform a deployment of Windows are the installation files from Windows 10 installation media.

segment.source: Even if you have an already prepared reference image, you still need to supply the unaltered installation files from your installation media.
segment.target: Even if you have an already prepared reference image, you still need to supply the unaltered installation files from your installation media.

segment.source: The source of these files can be a physical disk, or it can be an ISO file like the download from the Volume Licensing Service Center (VLSC).
segment.target: The source of these files can be a physical disk, or it can be an ISO file like the download from the Volume Licensing Service Center (VLSC).

segment.source: Note:A 64-bit operating system is required for compatibility with Surface Pro 4, Surface Book, Surface Pro 3, and Surface 3.
segment.target: Note:A 64-bit operating system is required for compatibility with Surface Pro 4, Surface Book, Surface Pro 3, and Surface 3.

segment.source: To import Windows 10 installation files, follow these steps:
segment.target: To import Windows 10 installation files, follow these steps:

segment.source: Right-click the Operating Systems folder under your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click New Folder to open the New Folder page, as shown in Figure 7.
segment.target: Right-click the Operating Systems folder under your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click New Folder to open the New Folder page, as shown in Figure 7.

segment.source: Create a new folder on the New Folder page
segment.target: Create a new folder on the New Folder page

segment.source: Figure 7.
segment.target: Figure 7.

segment.source: Create a new folder on the New Folder page
segment.target: Create a new folder on the New Folder page

segment.source: On the New Folder page a series of steps is displayed, as follows:
segment.target: On the New Folder page a series of steps is displayed, as follows:

segment.source: General Settings – Enter a name for the folder in the Folder Name field (for example, Windows 10 Enterprise), add any comments you want in the Comments field, and then click Next.
segment.target: General Settings – Enter a name for the folder in the Folder Name field (for example, Windows 10 Enterprise), add any comments you want in the Comments field, and then click Next.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration of the new folder on this page, and then click Next.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration of the new folder on this page, and then click Next.

segment.source: Progress – A progress bar will be displayed on this page while the folder is created.
segment.target: Progress – A progress bar will be displayed on this page while the folder is created.

segment.source: This page will likely pass very quickly.
segment.target: This page will likely pass very quickly.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the new folder has been created, a Confirmation page displays the success of the operation.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the new folder has been created, a Confirmation page displays the success of the operation.

segment.source: Click Finish to close the New Folder page.
segment.target: Click Finish to close the New Folder page.

segment.source: Expand the Operating Systems folder to see the newly created folder.
segment.target: Expand the Operating Systems folder to see the newly created folder.

segment.source: Right-click the newly created folder, and then click Import Operating System to launch the Import Operating System Wizard, as shown in Figure 8.
segment.target: Right-click the newly created folder, and then click Import Operating System to launch the Import Operating System Wizard, as shown in Figure 8.

segment.source: Import source files with the Import Operating System Wizard
segment.target: Import source files with the Import Operating System Wizard

segment.source: Figure 8.
segment.target: Figure 8.

segment.source: Import source files with the Import Operating System Wizard
segment.target: Import source files with the Import Operating System Wizard

segment.source: The Import Operating System Wizard walks you through the import of your operating system files, as follows:
segment.target: The Import Operating System Wizard walks you through the import of your operating system files, as follows:

segment.source: OS Type – Click Full Set of Source Files to specify that you are importing the Windows source files from installation media, and then click Next.
segment.target: OS Type – Click Full Set of Source Files to specify that you are importing the Windows source files from installation media, and then click Next.

segment.source: Source – Click Browse, move to and select the folder or drive where your installation files are found, and then click Next.
segment.target: Source – Click Browse, move to and select the folder or drive where your installation files are found, and then click Next.

segment.source: Destination – Enter a name for the new folder that will be created to hold the installation files, and then click Next.
segment.target: Destination – Enter a name for the new folder that will be created to hold the installation files, and then click Next.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin the import process.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin the import process.

segment.source: Progress – While the installation files are imported, a progress bar is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Progress – While the installation files are imported, a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the operating system import process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the operating system import process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete Import Operating System Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete Import Operating System Wizard.

segment.source: Expand the folder you created in Step 1 to see the entry for your newly imported installation files for Windows 10.
segment.target: Expand the folder you created in Step 1 to see the entry for your newly imported installation files for Windows 10.

segment.source: Now that you’ve imported the installation files from the installation media, you have the files that MDT needs to create the reference image and you are ready to instruct MDT how to create the reference image to your specifications.
segment.target: Now that you’ve imported the installation files from the installation media, you have the files that MDT needs to create the reference image and you are ready to instruct MDT how to create the reference image to your specifications.

segment.source: Create reference image task sequence
segment.target: Create reference image task sequence

segment.source: As described in the Deployment tools section of this article, the goal of creating a reference image is to keep the Windows environment as simple as possible while performing tasks that would be common to all devices being deployed.
segment.target: As described in the Deployment tools section of this article, the goal of creating a reference image is to keep the Windows environment as simple as possible while performing tasks that would be common to all devices being deployed.

segment.source: You should now have a basic MDT deployment share configured with default options and a set of unaltered, factory installation files for Windows 10.
segment.target: You should now have a basic MDT deployment share configured with default options and a set of unaltered, factory installation files for Windows 10.

segment.source: This simple configuration is perfect for reference image creation because the deployment share contains no applications or drivers to interfere with the process.
segment.target: This simple configuration is perfect for reference image creation because the deployment share contains no applications or drivers to interfere with the process.

segment.source: Note:For some organizations keeping a simple deployment share without applications or drivers is the simplest solution for creation of reference images.
segment.target: Note:For some organizations keeping a simple deployment share without applications or drivers is the simplest solution for creation of reference images.

segment.source: You can easily connect to more than one deployment share from a single Deployment Workbench and copy images from a simple, reference-image-only deployment share to a production deployment share complete with drivers and applications.
segment.target: You can easily connect to more than one deployment share from a single Deployment Workbench and copy images from a simple, reference-image-only deployment share to a production deployment share complete with drivers and applications.

segment.source: To create the reference image task sequence, follow these steps:
segment.target: To create the reference image task sequence, follow these steps:

segment.source: Right-click the Task Sequences folder under your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click New Task Sequence to start the New Task Sequence Wizard, as shown in Figure 9.
segment.target: Right-click the Task Sequences folder under your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click New Task Sequence to start the New Task Sequence Wizard, as shown in Figure 9.

segment.source: Create new task sequence to deploy and update a Windows 10 reference environment
segment.target: Create new task sequence to deploy and update a Windows 10 reference environment

segment.source: Figure 9.
segment.target: Figure 9.

segment.source: Create a new task sequence to deploy and update a Windows 10 reference environment
segment.target: Create a new task sequence to deploy and update a Windows 10 reference environment

segment.source: The New Task Sequence Wizard presents a series of steps, as follows:
segment.target: The New Task Sequence Wizard presents a series of steps, as follows:

segment.source: General Settings – Enter an identifier for the reference image task sequence in the Task Sequence ID field, a name for the reference image task sequence in the Task Sequence Name field, and any comments for the reference image task sequence in the Task Sequence Comments field, and then click Next.
segment.target: General Settings – Enter an identifier for the reference image task sequence in the Task Sequence ID field, a name for the reference image task sequence in the Task Sequence Name field, and any comments for the reference image task sequence in the Task Sequence Comments field, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note:The Task Sequence ID field cannot contain spaces and can be a maximum of 16 characters.
segment.target: Note:The Task Sequence ID field cannot contain spaces and can be a maximum of 16 characters.

segment.source: Select Template – Select Standard Client Task Sequence from the drop-down menu, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select Template – Select Standard Client Task Sequence from the drop-down menu, and then click Next.

segment.source: Select OS – Navigate to and select the Windows 10 image you imported with the Windows 10 installation files, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select OS – Navigate to and select the Windows 10 image you imported with the Windows 10 installation files, and then click Next.

segment.source: Specify Product Key – Click Do Not Specify a Product Key at This Time, and then click Next.
segment.target: Specify Product Key – Click Do Not Specify a Product Key at This Time, and then click Next.

segment.source: OS Settings – Enter a name, organization, and home page URL in the Full Name, Organization, and Internet Explorer Home Page fields, and then click Next.
segment.target: OS Settings – Enter a name, organization, and home page URL in the Full Name, Organization, and Internet Explorer Home Page fields, and then click Next.

segment.source: Admin Password – Click Use the Specified Local Administrator Password, enter a password in the provided field, and then click Next.
segment.target: Admin Password – Click Use the Specified Local Administrator Password, enter a password in the provided field, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note:During creation of a reference image, any specified Administrator password will be automatically removed when the image is prepared for capture with Sysprep.
segment.target: Note:During creation of a reference image, any specified Administrator password will be automatically removed when the image is prepared for capture with Sysprep.

segment.source: During reference image creation, a password is not necessary, but is recommended to remain in line with best practices for production deployment environments.
segment.target: During reference image creation, a password is not necessary, but is recommended to remain in line with best practices for production deployment environments.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the task sequence.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the task sequence.

segment.source: Progress – While the task sequence is created, a progress bar is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Progress – While the task sequence is created, a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the task sequence creation completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the task sequence creation completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete the New Task Sequence Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete the New Task Sequence Wizard.

segment.source: Select the Task Sequences folder, right-click the new task sequence you created, and then click Properties.
segment.target: Select the Task Sequences folder, right-click the new task sequence you created, and then click Properties.

segment.source: Select the Task Sequence tab to view the steps that are included in the Standard Client Task Sequence template, as shown in Figure 10.
segment.target: Select the Task Sequence tab to view the steps that are included in the Standard Client Task Sequence template, as shown in Figure 10.

segment.source: Enable Windows Update in the reference image task sequence
segment.target: Enable Windows Update in the reference image task sequence

segment.source: Figure 10.
segment.target: Figure 10.

segment.source: Enable Windows Update in the reference image task sequence
segment.target: Enable Windows Update in the reference image task sequence

segment.source: Select the Windows Update (Pre-Application Installation) option, located under the State Restore folder.
segment.target: Select the Windows Update (Pre-Application Installation) option, located under the State Restore folder.

segment.source: Click the Options tab, and then clear the Disable This Step check box.
segment.target: Click the Options tab, and then clear the Disable This Step check box.

segment.source: Repeat Step 4 and Step 5 for the Windows Update (Post-Application Installation) option.
segment.target: Repeat Step 4 and Step 5 for the Windows Update (Post-Application Installation) option.

segment.source: Click OK to apply changes to the task sequence, and then close the task sequence properties window.
segment.target: Click OK to apply changes to the task sequence, and then close the task sequence properties window.

segment.source: Generate and import MDT boot media
segment.target: Generate and import MDT boot media

segment.source: To boot the reference virtual machine from the network, the MDT deployment share first must be updated to generate boot media with the resources that have been added in the previous sections.
segment.target: To boot the reference virtual machine from the network, the MDT deployment share first must be updated to generate boot media with the resources that have been added in the previous sections.

segment.source: To update the MDT boot media, follow these steps:
segment.target: To update the MDT boot media, follow these steps:

segment.source: Right-click the deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click Update Deployment Share to start the Update Deployment Share Wizard, as shown in Figure 11.
segment.target: Right-click the deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click Update Deployment Share to start the Update Deployment Share Wizard, as shown in Figure 11.

segment.target: Generate boot images with the Update Deployment Share Wizard

segment.target: Options – Click Completely Regenerate the Boot Images, and then click Next.

segment.target: To import the MDT boot media into WDS for PXE boot, follow these steps:

segment.source: Expand Servers and your deployment server.

segment.source: The Add Image Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:
segment.target: The Add Image Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:

segment.source: Image File – Click Browse and navigate to the Boot folder in your deployment share, click LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, click Open, and then click Next.
segment.target: Image File – Click Browse and navigate to the Boot folder in your deployment share, click LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, click Open, and then click Next.

segment.source: Click Finish when the task is complete to close the Add Image Wizard.
