segment.source: Note:Only the 32-bit boot image, LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, is required to boot from BIOS devices, including Generation 1 Hyper-V virtual machines like the reference virtual machine.
segment.target: Note:Only the 32-bit boot image, LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, is required to boot from BIOS devices, including Generation 1 Hyper-V virtual machines like the reference virtual machine.

segment.source: If your WDS configuration is properly set up to respond to PXE clients, you should now be able to boot from the network with any device with a network adapter properly configured for network boot (PXE).
segment.target: If your WDS configuration is properly set up to respond to PXE clients, you should now be able to boot from the network with any device with a network adapter properly configured for network boot (PXE).

segment.source: Note:If your WDS server resides on the same server as DHCP or in a different subnet than the devices you are attempting to boot, additional configuration may be required.
segment.target: Note:If your WDS server resides on the same server as DHCP or in a different subnet than the devices you are attempting to boot, additional configuration may be required.

segment.source: For more information, see Managing Network Boot Programs.
segment.target: For more information, see Managing Network Boot Programs.

segment.source: Deploy and capture a reference image
segment.target: Deploy and capture a reference image

segment.source: Your deployment environment is now set up to create a reference image for Windows 10 complete with Windows Updates.
segment.target: Your deployment environment is now set up to create a reference image for Windows 10 complete with Windows Updates.

segment.source: Note:You cannot install version updates (such as Windows 10, Version 1511) in a reference image.
segment.target: Note:You cannot install version updates (such as Windows 10, Version 1511) in a reference image.

segment.source: To create a reference image with a new version of Windows, you must use installation files from that version of Windows.
segment.target: To create a reference image with a new version of Windows, you must use installation files from that version of Windows.

segment.source: When you install a version update in Windows, it effectively performs an upgrade to a new version of Windows, and upgraded installations of Windows cannot be prepared for deployment with Sysprep.
segment.target: When you install a version update in Windows, it effectively performs an upgrade to a new version of Windows, and upgraded installations of Windows cannot be prepared for deployment with Sysprep.

segment.source: By using a fully automated task sequence in an MDT deployment share dedicated to reference image creation, you can greatly reduce the time and effort required to create new reference images and it is the best way to ensure that your organization is ready for feature updates and new versions of Windows 10.
segment.target: By using a fully automated task sequence in an MDT deployment share dedicated to reference image creation, you can greatly reduce the time and effort required to create new reference images and it is the best way to ensure that your organization is ready for feature updates and new versions of Windows 10.

segment.source: You can now boot from the network with a virtual machine to run the prepared task sequence and generate a reference image.
segment.target: You can now boot from the network with a virtual machine to run the prepared task sequence and generate a reference image.

segment.source: When you prepare your virtual machine in Hyper-V for reference image creation, consider the following:
segment.target: When you prepare your virtual machine in Hyper-V for reference image creation, consider the following:

segment.source: Use a Generation 1 virtual machine for the simplicity of drivers and to ensure maximum compatibility with both BIOS and UEFI devices.
segment.target: Use a Generation 1 virtual machine for the simplicity of drivers and to ensure maximum compatibility with both BIOS and UEFI devices.

segment.source: Ensure your virtual machine has at least 1 GB of system memory at boot.
segment.target: Ensure your virtual machine has at least 1 GB of system memory at boot.

segment.source: You can ensure that the virtual machine has at least 1 GB of memory at boot but allow the memory to adjust after boot by using Dynamic Memory.
segment.target: You can ensure that the virtual machine has at least 1 GB of memory at boot but allow the memory to adjust after boot by using Dynamic Memory.

segment.source: You can read more about Dynamic Memory in the Hyper-V Dynamic Memory Overview.
segment.target: You can read more about Dynamic Memory in the Hyper-V Dynamic Memory Overview.

segment.source: Ensure your virtual machine uses a legacy network adapter to support network boot (PXE); that network adapter should be connected to the same network as your deployment server, and that network adapter should receive an IP address automatically via DHCP.
segment.target: Ensure your virtual machine uses a legacy network adapter to support network boot (PXE); that network adapter should be connected to the same network as your deployment server, and that network adapter should receive an IP address automatically via DHCP.

segment.source: Configure your boot order such that PXE Boot is the first option.
segment.target: Configure your boot order such that PXE Boot is the first option.

segment.source: When your virtual machine (VM) is properly configured and ready, start or boot the VM and be prepared to press the F12 key when prompted to boot via PXE from the WDS server.
segment.target: When your virtual machine (VM) is properly configured and ready, start or boot the VM and be prepared to press the F12 key when prompted to boot via PXE from the WDS server.

segment.source: Perform the reference image deployment and capture using the following steps:
segment.target: Perform the reference image deployment and capture using the following steps:

segment.source: Start your virtual machine and press the F12 key when prompted to boot to the WDS server via PXE, as shown in Figure 15.
segment.target: Start your virtual machine and press the F12 key when prompted to boot to the WDS server via PXE, as shown in Figure 15.

segment.source: Start network boot by pressing the F12 key
segment.target: Start network boot by pressing the F12 key

segment.source: Figure 15.
segment.target: Figure 15.

segment.source: Start network boot by pressing the F12 key
segment.target: Start network boot by pressing the F12 key

segment.source: Click Run the Deployment Wizard to Install a New Operating System to begin the MDT deployment process.
segment.target: Click Run the Deployment Wizard to Install a New Operating System to begin the MDT deployment process.

segment.source: Enter your MDT username and password, a user with rights to access the MDT deployment share over the network and with rights to write to the Captures folder in the deployment share.
segment.target: Enter your MDT username and password, a user with rights to access the MDT deployment share over the network and with rights to write to the Captures folder in the deployment share.

segment.source: After your credentials are validated, the Windows Deployment Wizard will start and process the boot and deployment share rules.
segment.target: After your credentials are validated, the Windows Deployment Wizard will start and process the boot and deployment share rules.

segment.source: The Windows Deployment Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:
segment.target: The Windows Deployment Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:

segment.source: Task Sequence – Select the task sequence you created for reference image creation (it should be the only task sequence available), and then click Next.
segment.target: Task Sequence – Select the task sequence you created for reference image creation (it should be the only task sequence available), and then click Next.

segment.source: Computer Details – Leave the default computer name, workgroup name, and the Join a Workgroup option selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: Computer Details – Leave the default computer name, workgroup name, and the Join a Workgroup option selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: The computer name and workgroup will be reset when the image is prepared by Sysprep and captured.
segment.target: The computer name and workgroup will be reset when the image is prepared by Sysprep and captured.

segment.source: Move Data and Settings – Leave the default option of Do Not Move User Data and Settings selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: Move Data and Settings – Leave the default option of Do Not Move User Data and Settings selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: User Data (Restore) – Leave the default option of Do Not Restore User Data and Settings selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: User Data (Restore) – Leave the default option of Do Not Restore User Data and Settings selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: Locale and Time – Leave the default options for language and time settings selected.
segment.target: Locale and Time – Leave the default options for language and time settings selected.

segment.source: The locale and time settings will be specified during deployment of the image to other devices.
segment.target: The locale and time settings will be specified during deployment of the image to other devices.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Capture Image – Click the Capture an Image of this Reference Computer option, as shown in Figure 16.
segment.target: Capture Image – Click the Capture an Image of this Reference Computer option, as shown in Figure 16.

segment.source: In the Location field, keep the default location of the Captures folder.
segment.target: In the Location field, keep the default location of the Captures folder.

segment.source: You can keep or change the name of the image file in the File Name field.
segment.target: You can keep or change the name of the image file in the File Name field.

segment.source: When you are finished, click Next.
segment.target: When you are finished, click Next.

segment.source: Capture an image of the reference machine
segment.target: Capture an image of the reference machine

segment.source: Figure 16.
segment.target: Figure 16.

segment.source: Use the Capture Image page to capture an image of the reference machine after deployment
segment.target: Use the Capture Image page to capture an image of the reference machine after deployment

segment.source: Ready – You can review your selections by expanding Details on the Ready page.
segment.target: Ready – You can review your selections by expanding Details on the Ready page.

segment.source: Click Begin when you are ready to perform the deployment and capture of your reference image.
segment.target: Click Begin when you are ready to perform the deployment and capture of your reference image.

segment.source: Your reference task sequence will run with the specified options.
segment.target: Your reference task sequence will run with the specified options.

segment.source: As the task sequence processes the deployment, it will automatically perform the following tasks:
segment.target: As the task sequence processes the deployment, it will automatically perform the following tasks:

segment.source: Install the Windows 10 image from the installation files you supplied
segment.target: Install the Windows 10 image from the installation files you supplied

segment.source: Reboot into Windows 10
segment.target: Reboot into Windows 10

segment.source: Run Windows updates until all Windows updates have been installed and the Windows environment is fully up to date
segment.target: Run Windows updates until all Windows updates have been installed and the Windows environment is fully up to date

segment.source: Run Sysprep and prepare the Windows 10 environment for deployment
segment.target: Run Sysprep and prepare the Windows 10 environment for deployment

segment.source: Reboot into WinPE
segment.target: Reboot into WinPE

segment.source: Capture an image of the Windows 10 environment and store it in the Captures folder in the MDT deployment share
segment.target: Capture an image of the Windows 10 environment and store it in the Captures folder in the MDT deployment share

segment.source: Note:The Windows Update process can take some time to complete as it searches the Internet for updates, downloads those updates, and then installs them.
segment.target: Note:The Windows Update process can take some time to complete as it searches the Internet for updates, downloads those updates, and then installs them.

segment.source: By performing this process now, in the reference environment, you eliminate the need to perform these tasks on each deployed device and significantly reduce the amount of time and bandwidth required to perform your deployment.
segment.target: By performing this process now, in the reference environment, you eliminate the need to perform these tasks on each deployed device and significantly reduce the amount of time and bandwidth required to perform your deployment.

segment.source: When the task sequence completes, your virtual machine will be off and a new reference image complete with updates will be ready in your MDT deployment share for you to import it and prepare your deployment environment for deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: When the task sequence completes, your virtual machine will be off and a new reference image complete with updates will be ready in your MDT deployment share for you to import it and prepare your deployment environment for deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 to Surface devices

segment.source: With a freshly prepared reference image, you are now ready to configure the deployment process for deployment to the Surface devices.
segment.target: With a freshly prepared reference image, you are now ready to configure the deployment process for deployment to the Surface devices.

segment.source: Use the steps detailed in this section to produce a deployment process that requires minimal effort on each Surface device to produce a complete and ready-to-use Windows 10 environment.
segment.target: Use the steps detailed in this section to produce a deployment process that requires minimal effort on each Surface device to produce a complete and ready-to-use Windows 10 environment.

segment.source: Import reference image
segment.target: Import reference image

segment.source: After the reference image has been created and stored in the Captures folder, you need to add it to your MDT deployment share as an image for deployment.
segment.target: After the reference image has been created and stored in the Captures folder, you need to add it to your MDT deployment share as an image for deployment.

segment.source: You perform this task by using the same process that you used to import the installation files for Windows 10.
segment.target: You perform this task by using the same process that you used to import the installation files for Windows 10.

segment.source: To import the reference image for deployment, use the following steps:
segment.target: To import the reference image for deployment, use the following steps:

segment.source: Right-click the Operating Systems folder under your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench or the folder you created in when you imported Windows 10 installation files, and then click Import Operating System to start the Import Operating System Wizard.
segment.target: Right-click the Operating Systems folder under your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench or the folder you created in when you imported Windows 10 installation files, and then click Import Operating System to start the Import Operating System Wizard.

segment.source: Import the custom image with the Import Operating System Wizard by using the following steps:
segment.target: Import the custom image with the Import Operating System Wizard by using the following steps:

segment.source: OS Type – Select Custom Image File to specify that you are importing the Windows source files from installation media, and then click Next.
segment.target: OS Type – Select Custom Image File to specify that you are importing the Windows source files from installation media, and then click Next.

segment.source: Image – Click Browse, and then navigate to and select the image file in the Captures folder in your deployment share.
segment.target: Image – Click Browse, and then navigate to and select the image file in the Captures folder in your deployment share.

segment.source: Select the Move the Files to the Deployment Share Instead of Copying Them checkbox if desired.
segment.target: Select the Move the Files to the Deployment Share Instead of Copying Them checkbox if desired.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Setup – Click Setup Files are not Neededf, and then click Next.
segment.target: Setup – Click Setup Files are not Neededf, and then click Next.

segment.source: Destination – Enter a name for the new folder that will be created to hold the image file, and then click Next.
segment.target: Destination – Enter a name for the new folder that will be created to hold the image file, and then click Next.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin the import process.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin the import process.

segment.source: Progress – While the image is imported, a progress bar is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Progress – While the image is imported, a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the import process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the import process completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete the Import Operating System Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete the Import Operating System Wizard.

segment.source: Expand the folder in which you imported the image to verify that the import completed successfully.
segment.target: Expand the folder in which you imported the image to verify that the import completed successfully.

segment.source: Note:You can import the reference image into the same deployment share that you used to create your reference image, or you could import the reference image into a new deployment share for deployment to your Surface devices.
segment.target: Note:You can import the reference image into the same deployment share that you used to create your reference image, or you could import the reference image into a new deployment share for deployment to your Surface devices.

segment.source: If you chose to create a new deployment share for deployment of your reference image, remember that you still need to import a full set of installation files from installation media.
segment.target: If you chose to create a new deployment share for deployment of your reference image, remember that you still need to import a full set of installation files from installation media.

segment.source: Now that your updated reference image is imported, it is time to prepare your deployment environment for deployment to Surface devices complete with drivers, applications, and automation.
segment.target: Now that your updated reference image is imported, it is time to prepare your deployment environment for deployment to Surface devices complete with drivers, applications, and automation.

segment.source: Import Surface drivers
segment.target: Import Surface drivers

segment.source: Before you can deploy your updated reference image to Surface devices, or any physical environment, you need to supply MDT with the drivers that Windows will use to communicate with that physical environment.
segment.target: Before you can deploy your updated reference image to Surface devices, or any physical environment, you need to supply MDT with the drivers that Windows will use to communicate with that physical environment.

segment.source: For Surface devices you can download all of the drivers required by Windows in a single archive (.zip) file in a format that is ready for deployment.
segment.target: For Surface devices you can download all of the drivers required by Windows in a single archive (.zip) file in a format that is ready for deployment.

segment.source: In addition to the drivers that are used by Windows to communicate with the hardware and components, Surface firmware and driver packs also include updates for the firmware of those components.
segment.target: In addition to the drivers that are used by Windows to communicate with the hardware and components, Surface firmware and driver packs also include updates for the firmware of those components.

segment.source: By installing the Surface firmware and driver pack, you will also bring your device’s firmware up to date.
segment.target: By installing the Surface firmware and driver pack, you will also bring your device’s firmware up to date.

segment.source: If you have not done so already, download the drivers for your Surface device listed at Download the latest firmware and drivers for Surface devices.
segment.target: If you have not done so already, download the drivers for your Surface device listed at Download the latest firmware and drivers for Surface devices.

segment.source: Many devices require that you import drivers specifically for WinPE in order for the MDT boot media to communicate with the deployment share and to boot properly on that device.
segment.target: Many devices require that you import drivers specifically for WinPE in order for the MDT boot media to communicate with the deployment share and to boot properly on that device.

segment.source: Even Surface Pro 3 required that network drivers be imported specifically for WinPE for deployment of Windows 8.1.
segment.target: Even Surface Pro 3 required that network drivers be imported specifically for WinPE for deployment of Windows 8.1.

segment.source: Fortunately, for Windows 10 deployments to Surface devices, all of the required drivers for operation of WinPE are contained within the out-of-box drivers that are built into Windows 10.
segment.target: Fortunately, for Windows 10 deployments to Surface devices, all of the required drivers for operation of WinPE are contained within the out-of-box drivers that are built into Windows 10.

segment.source: It is still a good idea to prepare your environment with folder structure and selection profiles that allow you to specify drivers for use in WinPE.
segment.target: It is still a good idea to prepare your environment with folder structure and selection profiles that allow you to specify drivers for use in WinPE.

segment.source: You can read more about that folder structure in Step 5: Prepare the drivers repository in Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2.
segment.target: You can read more about that folder structure in Step 5: Prepare the drivers repository in Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2.

segment.source: To import the Surface drivers (in this example, Surface Pro 4) into MDT, follow these steps:
segment.target: To import the Surface drivers (in this example, Surface Pro 4) into MDT, follow these steps:

segment.source: Extract the downloaded archive (.zip) file to a folder that you can easily locate.
segment.target: Extract the downloaded archive (.zip) file to a folder that you can easily locate.

segment.source: Keep the driver files separate from other drivers or files.
segment.target: Keep the driver files separate from other drivers or files.

segment.source: Open the Deployment Workbench and expand the Deployment Shares node and your deployment share.
segment.target: Open the Deployment Workbench and expand the Deployment Shares node and your deployment share.

segment.source: If you have not already created a folder structure by operating system version, you should do so now and create under the Windows 10 x64 folder a new folder for Surface Pro 4 drivers named Surface Pro 4.
segment.target: If you have not already created a folder structure by operating system version, you should do so now and create under the Windows 10 x64 folder a new folder for Surface Pro 4 drivers named Surface Pro 4.

segment.target: Right-click the Surface Pro 4 folder, and then click Import Drivers to start the Import Drivers Wizard, as shown in Figure 18.

segment.source: Import applications
segment.target: Import applications

segment.source: You can import any number of applications into MDT for installation on your devices during the deployment process.
segment.target: You can import any number of applications into MDT for installation on your devices during the deployment process.

segment.source: You can configure your applications and task sequences to prompt you during deployment to pick and choose which applications are installed, or you can use your task sequence to explicitly define which applications are installed.
segment.target: You can configure your applications and task sequences to prompt you during deployment to pick and choose which applications are installed, or you can use your task sequence to explicitly define which applications are installed.

segment.target: For more information, see Step 4: Add an application in Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2.

segment.source: Import Microsoft Office 365 Installer
segment.target: Import Microsoft Office 365 Installer

segment.source: The Office Deployment Tool is a free download available in the Microsoft Download Center that allows IT professionals and system administrators to download and prepare Office installation packages for Office Click-to-Run.
segment.target: The Office Deployment Tool is a free download available in the Microsoft Download Center that allows IT professionals and system administrators to download and prepare Office installation packages for Office Click-to-Run.

segment.source: You can find the Office Deployment Tool and instructions to download Click-to-Run for Office 365 installation source files at Download Click-to-Run for Office 365 products by using the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: You can find the Office Deployment Tool and instructions to download Click-to-Run for Office 365 installation source files at Download Click-to-Run for Office 365 products by using the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: Download and install the version of Office Deployment Tool (ODT), for Office 2013 or Office 2016, that fits your organization’s needs and use the steps provided by that page to download the Office installation files for use with MDT.
segment.target: Download and install the version of Office Deployment Tool (ODT), for Office 2013 or Office 2016, that fits your organization’s needs and use the steps provided by that page to download the Office installation files for use with MDT.

segment.source: After you have downloaded the source files for your version of Office Click-to-Run, you need to edit the Configuration.xml file with instructions to install Office Click-to-Run silently.
segment.target: After you have downloaded the source files for your version of Office Click-to-Run, you need to edit the Configuration.xml file with instructions to install Office Click-to-Run silently.

segment.source: To configure the Office Deployment Tool for silent installation, follow these steps:
segment.target: To configure the Office Deployment Tool for silent installation, follow these steps:

segment.source: Right-click the existing Configuration.xml file, and then click Edit.
segment.target: Right-click the existing Configuration.xml file, and then click Edit.

segment.source: This action opens the file in Notepad.
segment.target: This action opens the file in Notepad.

segment.source: Replace the existing text with the following:
segment.target: Replace the existing text with the following:

segment.source: Save the file.
segment.target: Save the file.

segment.source: The default behavior of Setup.exe is to look for the source files in the path that contains Setup.exe.
segment.target: The default behavior of Setup.exe is to look for the source files in the path that contains Setup.exe.

segment.source: If the installation files are not found in this folder, the Office Deployment Tool will default to online source files from an Internet connection.
segment.target: If the installation files are not found in this folder, the Office Deployment Tool will default to online source files from an Internet connection.

segment.source: For MDT to perform an automated installation of office, it is important to configure the Display Level option to a value of None.
segment.target: For MDT to perform an automated installation of office, it is important to configure the Display Level option to a value of None.

segment.source: This setting is used to suppress the installation dialog box for silent installation.
segment.target: This setting is used to suppress the installation dialog box for silent installation.

segment.source: It is required that the AcceptEULA option is set to True to accept the license agreement when the Display Level option is set to None.
segment.target: It is required that the AcceptEULA option is set to True to accept the license agreement when the Display Level option is set to None.

segment.source: With both of these options configured, the installation of Office will occur without the display of dialog boxes which could potentially cause the installation to pause until a user can address an open dialog box.
segment.target: With both of these options configured, the installation of Office will occur without the display of dialog boxes which could potentially cause the installation to pause until a user can address an open dialog box.

segment.source: Now that the installation and configuration files are prepared, the application can be imported into the deployment share by following these steps:
segment.target: Now that the installation and configuration files are prepared, the application can be imported into the deployment share by following these steps:

segment.source: Open the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: Open the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Expand the deployment share, right-click the Applications folder, and then click New Application to start the New Application Wizard, as shown in Figure 20.
segment.target: Expand the deployment share, right-click the Applications folder, and then click New Application to start the New Application Wizard, as shown in Figure 20.

segment.target: Command Details – Enter the Office Deployment Tool installation command line:

segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin the import process.

segment.target: Progress – While the installation files are imported, a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: You should now see the Office 2016 Click-to-Run item under the Applications folder in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: You should now see the Office 2016 Click-to-Run item under the Applications folder in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Import Surface app installer
segment.target: Import Surface app installer

segment.source: The Surface app is a Windows Store app that provides the user with greater control over specific Surface device functions and capabilities (for example, control over the sensitivity of the Surface Pen).
segment.target: The Surface app is a Windows Store app that provides the user with greater control over specific Surface device functions and capabilities (for example, control over the sensitivity of the Surface Pen).

segment.source: It is a highly recommended app for Surface devices to provide end users with the best experience and greatest control over their device.
segment.target: It is a highly recommended app for Surface devices to provide end users with the best experience and greatest control over their device.

segment.source: Find out more about the Surface app at Install and use the Surface app.
segment.target: Find out more about the Surface app at Install and use the Surface app.

segment.source: To perform a deployment of the Surface app, you will need to download the app files through Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: To perform a deployment of the Surface app, you will need to download the app files through Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: You can find detailed instructions on how to download the Surface app through Windows Store for Business at Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: You can find detailed instructions on how to download the Surface app through Windows Store for Business at Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: After you have downloaded the installation files for Surface app, including the AppxBundle and license files, you can import these files into the deployment share through the same process as a desktop application like Microsoft Office.
segment.target: After you have downloaded the installation files for Surface app, including the AppxBundle and license files, you can import these files into the deployment share through the same process as a desktop application like Microsoft Office.

segment.source: Both the AppxBundle and license files must be together in the same folder for the import process to complete successfully.
segment.target: Both the AppxBundle and license files must be together in the same folder for the import process to complete successfully.

segment.source: Use the following command on the Command Details page to install the Surface app:
segment.target: Use the following command on the Command Details page to install the Surface app:

segment.source: Create deployment task sequence
segment.target: Create deployment task sequence

segment.source: The next step in the process is to create the deployment task sequence.
segment.target: The next step in the process is to create the deployment task sequence.

segment.source: This task sequence will be configured to completely automate the deployment process and will work along with customized deployment share rules to reduce the need for user interaction down to a single touch.
segment.target: This task sequence will be configured to completely automate the deployment process and will work along with customized deployment share rules to reduce the need for user interaction down to a single touch.

segment.source: Before you can make customizations to include all of this automation, the new task sequence has to be created from a template.
segment.target: Before you can make customizations to include all of this automation, the new task sequence has to be created from a template.

segment.source: To create the deployment task sequence, follow these steps:
segment.target: To create the deployment task sequence, follow these steps:

segment.source: In the Deployment Workbench, under your Deployment Share, right-click the Task Sequences folder, and then click New Task Sequence to start the New Task Sequence Wizard.
segment.target: In the Deployment Workbench, under your Deployment Share, right-click the Task Sequences folder, and then click New Task Sequence to start the New Task Sequence Wizard.

segment.source: Use these steps to create the deployment task sequence with the New Task Sequence Wizard:
segment.target: Use these steps to create the deployment task sequence with the New Task Sequence Wizard:

segment.source: General Settings – Enter an identifier for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence ID field, a name for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Name field, and any comments for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Comments field, then click Next.
segment.target: General Settings – Enter an identifier for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence ID field, a name for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Name field, and any comments for the deployment task sequence in the Task Sequence Comments field, then click Next.

segment.source: Note:The Task Sequence ID field cannot contain spaces and can be a maximum of 16 characters.
segment.target: Note:The Task Sequence ID field cannot contain spaces and can be a maximum of 16 characters.

segment.source: Select Template – Click Standard Client Task Sequence from the drop-down menu, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select Template – Click Standard Client Task Sequence from the drop-down menu, and then click Next.

segment.source: Select OS – Navigate to and select the reference image that you imported, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select OS – Navigate to and select the reference image that you imported, and then click Next.

segment.source: Specify Product Key – Select the product key entry that fits your organization's licensing system.
segment.target: Specify Product Key – Select the product key entry that fits your organization's licensing system.

segment.source: The Do Not Specify a Product Key at This Time option can be used for systems that will be activated via Key Management Services (KMS) or Active Directory Based Activation (ADBA).
segment.target: The Do Not Specify a Product Key at This Time option can be used for systems that will be activated via Key Management Services (KMS) or Active Directory Based Activation (ADBA).

segment.source: A product key can be specified specifically if your organization uses Multiple Activation Keys (MAK).
segment.target: A product key can be specified specifically if your organization uses Multiple Activation Keys (MAK).

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: OS Settings – Enter a name and organization for registration of Windows, and a home page URL for users when they browse the Internet in the Full Name, Organization, and Internet Explorer Home Page fields, and then click Next.
segment.target: OS Settings – Enter a name and organization for registration of Windows, and a home page URL for users when they browse the Internet in the Full Name, Organization, and Internet Explorer Home Page fields, and then click Next.

segment.source: Admin Password – Click Use the Specified Local Administrator Password, enter a password in the provided field, and then click Next.
segment.target: Admin Password – Click Use the Specified Local Administrator Password, enter a password in the provided field, and then click Next.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the task sequence.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified configuration on this page before you click Next to begin creation of the task sequence.

segment.source: Progress – While the task sequence is being created, a progress bar is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Progress – While the task sequence is being created, a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the task sequence creation completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the task sequence creation completes, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete the New Task Sequence Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete the New Task Sequence Wizard.

segment.source: After the task sequence is created it can be modified for increased automation, such as the installation of applications without user interaction, the selection of drivers, and the installation of Windows updates.
segment.target: After the task sequence is created it can be modified for increased automation, such as the installation of applications without user interaction, the selection of drivers, and the installation of Windows updates.

segment.source: Click the Task Sequences folder, right-click the new task sequence you created, and then click Properties.
segment.target: Click the Task Sequences folder, right-click the new task sequence you created, and then click Properties.

segment.source: Click the Task Sequence tab to view the steps that are included in the new task sequence.
segment.target: Click the Task Sequence tab to view the steps that are included in the new task sequence.

segment.source: Click the Windows Update (Pre-Application Installation) step, located under the State Restore folder.
segment.target: Click the Windows Update (Pre-Application Installation) step, located under the State Restore folder.

segment.source: Click the Options tab, and then clear the Disable This Step check box.
segment.target: Click the Options tab, and then clear the Disable This Step check box.

segment.source: Repeat Step 4 and Step 5 for the Windows Update (Post-Application Installation) option.
segment.target: Repeat Step 4 and Step 5 for the Windows Update (Post-Application Installation) option.

segment.source: Between the two Windows Update steps is the Install Applications step.
segment.target: Between the two Windows Update steps is the Install Applications step.

segment.source: Click the Install Applications step, and then click Add.
segment.target: Click the Install Applications step, and then click Add.

segment.source: Hover the mouse over General under the Add menu, and then click Install Application.
segment.target: Hover the mouse over General under the Add menu, and then click Install Application.

segment.source: This will add a new step after the selected step for the installation of a specific application as shown in Figure 21.
segment.target: This will add a new step after the selected step for the installation of a specific application as shown in Figure 21.

segment.target: A new Install Application step in the deployment task sequence

segment.target: A new Install Application step in the deployment task sequence

segment.source: On the Properties tab of the new Install Application step, enter Install Microsoft Office 2016 Click-to-Run in the Name field.
segment.target: On the Properties tab of the new Install Application step, enter Install Microsoft Office 2016 Click-to-Run in the Name field.

segment.source: Click Install a Single Application, and then click Browse to view available applications that have been imported into the deployment share.
segment.target: Click Install a Single Application, and then click Browse to view available applications that have been imported into the deployment share.

segment.source: Select Office 2016 Click-to-Run from the list of applications, and then click OK.
segment.target: Select Office 2016 Click-to-Run from the list of applications, and then click OK.

segment.source: Repeat Steps 6 through 10 for the Surface app.
segment.target: Repeat Steps 6 through 10 for the Surface app.

segment.source: Expand the Preinstall folder, and then click the Enable BitLocker (Offline) step.
segment.target: Expand the Preinstall folder, and then click the Enable BitLocker (Offline) step.

segment.source: Open the Add menu again and choose Set Task Sequence Variable from under the General menu.
segment.target: Open the Add menu again and choose Set Task Sequence Variable from under the General menu.

segment.source: On the Properties tab of the new Set Task Sequence Variable step (as shown in Figure 22), configure the following options:
segment.target: On the Properties tab of the new Set Task Sequence Variable step (as shown in Figure 22), configure the following options:

segment.source: Name – Set DriverGroup001
segment.target: Name – Set DriverGroup001

segment.source: Task Sequence Variable – DriverGroup001
segment.target: Task Sequence Variable – DriverGroup001

segment.source: Value – Windows 10 x64\%Make%\%Model%
segment.target: Value – Windows 10 x64\%Make%\%Model%

segment.source: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence
segment.target: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence

segment.source: Figure 22.
segment.target: Figure 22.

segment.source: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence
segment.target: Configure a new Set Task Sequence Variable step in the deployment task sequence

segment.source: Select the Inject Drivers step, the next step in the task sequence.
segment.target: Select the Inject Drivers step, the next step in the task sequence.

segment.source: On the Properties tab of the Inject Drivers step (as shown in Figure 23), configure the following options:
segment.target: On the Properties tab of the Inject Drivers step (as shown in Figure 23), configure the following options:

segment.source: In the Choose a selection profile drop-down menu, select Nothing.
segment.target: In the Choose a selection profile drop-down menu, select Nothing.

segment.source: Click the Install all drivers from the selection profile button.
segment.target: Click the Install all drivers from the selection profile button.

segment.source: Configure deployment task sequence not to choose the drivers to inject into Windows
segment.target: Configure deployment task sequence not to choose the drivers to inject into Windows

segment.source: Figure 23.
segment.target: Figure 23.

segment.source: Configure the deployment task sequence not to choose the drivers to inject into Windows
segment.target: Configure the deployment task sequence not to choose the drivers to inject into Windows

segment.source: Click OK to apply changes to the task sequence and close the task sequence properties window.
segment.target: Click OK to apply changes to the task sequence and close the task sequence properties window.

segment.source: Configure deployment share rules
segment.target: Configure deployment share rules

segment.source: The experience of users during a Windows deployment is largely governed by a set of rules that control how the MDT and Windows Deployment Wizard experience should proceed.
segment.target: The experience of users during a Windows deployment is largely governed by a set of rules that control how the MDT and Windows Deployment Wizard experience should proceed.

segment.source: These rules are stored in two configuration files.
segment.target: These rules are stored in two configuration files.

segment.source: Boot media rules are stored in the Bootstrap.ini file that is processed when the MDT boot media is first run.
segment.target: Boot media rules are stored in the Bootstrap.ini file that is processed when the MDT boot media is first run.

segment.source: Deployment share rules are stored in the Customsettings.ini file and tell the Windows Deployment Wizard how to operate (for example, what screens to show and what questions to ask).
segment.target: Deployment share rules are stored in the Customsettings.ini file and tell the Windows Deployment Wizard how to operate (for example, what screens to show and what questions to ask).

segment.source: By using these the rules stored in these two files, you can completely automate the process of deployment to where you will not be asked to supply the answer to any questions during deployment and the deployment will perform all tasks completely on its own.
segment.target: By using these the rules stored in these two files, you can completely automate the process of deployment to where you will not be asked to supply the answer to any questions during deployment and the deployment will perform all tasks completely on its own.

segment.source: Configure Bootstrap.ini
segment.target: Configure Bootstrap.ini

segment.source: Bootstrap.ini is the simpler of the two rule files.
segment.target: Bootstrap.ini is the simpler of the two rule files.

segment.source: The purpose it serves is to provide instructions from when the MDT boot media starts on a device until the Windows Deployment Wizard is started.
segment.target: The purpose it serves is to provide instructions from when the MDT boot media starts on a device until the Windows Deployment Wizard is started.

segment.source: The primary use of this file is to provide the credentials that will be used to log on to the deployment share and start the Windows Deployment Wizard.
segment.target: The primary use of this file is to provide the credentials that will be used to log on to the deployment share and start the Windows Deployment Wizard.

segment.source: To automate the boot media rules, follow these steps:
segment.target: To automate the boot media rules, follow these steps:

segment.source: Right-click your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click Properties.
segment.target: Right-click your deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click Properties.

segment.source: Click the Rules tab, and then click Edit Bootstrap.ini to open Bootstrap.ini in Notepad.
segment.target: Click the Rules tab, and then click Edit Bootstrap.ini to open Bootstrap.ini in Notepad.

segment.source: Replace the text of the Bootstrap.ini file with the following text:
segment.target: Replace the text of the Bootstrap.ini file with the following text:

segment.source: Press Ctrl+S to save Bootstrap.ini, and then close Notepad.
segment.target: Press Ctrl+S to save Bootstrap.ini, and then close Notepad.

segment.source: You can use a number of variables in both boot media and deployment share rules to apply rules only when certain conditions are met.
segment.target: You can use a number of variables in both boot media and deployment share rules to apply rules only when certain conditions are met.

segment.source: For example, you can use MAC addresses to identify specific machines where MDT will run fully automated, but will run with required user interaction on all other devices.
segment.target: For example, you can use MAC addresses to identify specific machines where MDT will run fully automated, but will run with required user interaction on all other devices.

segment.source: You can also use the model of the device to instruct the MDT boot media to perform different actions based on computer model, much as the way [Surface Pro 4] is listed in Step 3.
segment.target: You can also use the model of the device to instruct the MDT boot media to perform different actions based on computer model, much as the way [Surface Pro 4] is listed in Step 3.

segment.source: You can use the following cmdlet in a PowerShell session to see what the Model variable would be on a device:
segment.target: You can use the following cmdlet in a PowerShell session to see what the Model variable would be on a device:

segment.source: Rules used in the text shown in Step 3 include:
segment.target: Rules used in the text shown in Step 3 include:

segment.source: DeployRoot – Used to specify the deployment share that the MDT boot media will connect to.
segment.target: DeployRoot – Used to specify the deployment share that the MDT boot media will connect to.

segment.source: UserDomain – Used to specify the domain or computer where the MDT user account is located.
segment.target: UserDomain – Used to specify the domain or computer where the MDT user account is located.

segment.source: UserID – Used to specify the MDT user account for automatic logon to the deployment share.
segment.target: UserID – Used to specify the MDT user account for automatic logon to the deployment share.

segment.source: UserPassword – Used to specify the MDT user password for automatic logon to the deployment share.
segment.target: UserPassword – Used to specify the MDT user password for automatic logon to the deployment share.

segment.source: SkipBDDWelcome – Used to skip the Welcome page and to start the Windows Deployment Wizard immediately using the specified credentials and deployment share.
segment.target: SkipBDDWelcome – Used to skip the Welcome page and to start the Windows Deployment Wizard immediately using the specified credentials and deployment share.

segment.source: Configure CustomSettings.ini
segment.target: Configure CustomSettings.ini

segment.source: The bulk of the rules used to automate the MDT deployment process are stored in the deployment share rules, or the Customsettings.ini file.
segment.target: The bulk of the rules used to automate the MDT deployment process are stored in the deployment share rules, or the Customsettings.ini file.

segment.source: In this file you can answer and hide all of the prompts from the Windows Deployment Wizard, which yields a deployment experience that mostly consists of a progress bar that displays the automated actions occurring on the device.
segment.target: In this file you can answer and hide all of the prompts from the Windows Deployment Wizard, which yields a deployment experience that mostly consists of a progress bar that displays the automated actions occurring on the device.

segment.source: The deployment share rules are shown directly in the Rules tab of the deployment share properties, as shown in Figure 24.
segment.target: The deployment share rules are shown directly in the Rules tab of the deployment share properties, as shown in Figure 24.

segment.source: Deployment share rules configured for automation of the Windows Deployment Wizard
segment.target: Deployment share rules configured for automation of the Windows Deployment Wizard

segment.source: Figure 24.
segment.target: Figure 24.

segment.source: Deployment share rules configured for automation of the Windows Deployment Wizard
segment.target: Deployment share rules configured for automation of the Windows Deployment Wizard

segment.source: To configure automation for the production deployment, copy and paste the following text into the text box on the Rules tab of your deployment share properties:
segment.target: To configure automation for the production deployment, copy and paste the following text into the text box on the Rules tab of your deployment share properties:

segment.source: Rules used in this example include:
segment.target: Rules used in this example include:

segment.source: SkipTaskSequence – This rule is used to skip the Task Sequence page where the user would have to select between available task sequences.
segment.target: SkipTaskSequence – This rule is used to skip the Task Sequence page where the user would have to select between available task sequences.

segment.source: TaskSequenceID – This rule is used to instruct the Windows Deployment Wizard to run a specific task sequence.
segment.target: TaskSequenceID – This rule is used to instruct the Windows Deployment Wizard to run a specific task sequence.

segment.source: In this scenario the task sequence ID should match the deployment task sequence you created in the previous section.
segment.target: In this scenario the task sequence ID should match the deployment task sequence you created in the previous section.

segment.source: OSInstall – This rule indicates that the Windows Deployment Wizard will be performing an operating system deployment.
segment.target: OSInstall – This rule indicates that the Windows Deployment Wizard will be performing an operating system deployment.

segment.source: SkipCapture – This rule prevents the Capture Image page from being displayed, prompting the user to create an image of this device after deployment.
segment.target: SkipCapture – This rule prevents the Capture Image page from being displayed, prompting the user to create an image of this device after deployment.

segment.source: SkipAdminPassword – This rule prevents the Admin Password page from being displayed.
segment.target: SkipAdminPassword – This rule prevents the Admin Password page from being displayed.

segment.source: The Administrator password specified in the task sequence will still be applied.
segment.target: The Administrator password specified in the task sequence will still be applied.

segment.source: SkipProductKey – This rule prevents the Specify Product Key page from being displayed.
segment.target: SkipProductKey – This rule prevents the Specify Product Key page from being displayed.

segment.source: The product key specified in the task sequence will still be applied.
segment.target: The product key specified in the task sequence will still be applied.

segment.source: SkipComputerBackup – This rule prevents the Move Data and Settings page from being displayed, where the user is asked if they would like to make a backup of the computer before performing deployment.
segment.target: SkipComputerBackup – This rule prevents the Move Data and Settings page from being displayed, where the user is asked if they would like to make a backup of the computer before performing deployment.

segment.source: SkipBitLocker – This rule prevents the BitLocker page from being displayed, where the user is asked if BitLocker Drive Encryption should be used to encrypt the device.
segment.target: SkipBitLocker – This rule prevents the BitLocker page from being displayed, where the user is asked if BitLocker Drive Encryption should be used to encrypt the device.

segment.source: SkipBDDWelcome – This rule prevents the Welcome page from being displayed, where the user is prompted to begin Windows deployment.
segment.target: SkipBDDWelcome – This rule prevents the Welcome page from being displayed, where the user is prompted to begin Windows deployment.

segment.source: SkipUserData – This rule prevents the User Data (Restore) page from being displayed, where the user is asked to restore previously backed up user data in the new environment.
segment.target: SkipUserData – This rule prevents the User Data (Restore) page from being displayed, where the user is asked to restore previously backed up user data in the new environment.

segment.source: UserDataLocation – This rule prevents the user from being prompted to supply a location on the User Data (Restore) page.
segment.target: UserDataLocation – This rule prevents the user from being prompted to supply a location on the User Data (Restore) page.

segment.source: SkipApplications – This rule prevents the Applications page from being displayed, where the user is prompted to select from available applications to be installed in the new environment.
segment.target: SkipApplications – This rule prevents the Applications page from being displayed, where the user is prompted to select from available applications to be installed in the new environment.

segment.source: SkipPackageDisplay – This rule prevents the Packages page from being displayed, where the user is prompted to select from available packages to be installed in the new environment.
segment.target: SkipPackageDisplay – This rule prevents the Packages page from being displayed, where the user is prompted to select from available packages to be installed in the new environment.

segment.source: SkipComputerName – This rule, when combined with the SkipDomainMembership rule, prevents the Computer Details page from being displayed, where the user is asked to supply computer name and join a domain or workgroup.
segment.target: SkipComputerName – This rule, when combined with the SkipDomainMembership rule, prevents the Computer Details page from being displayed, where the user is asked to supply computer name and join a domain or workgroup.

segment.source: SkipDomainMembership – This rule, when combined with the SkipComputerName rule, prevents the Computer Details page from being displayed, where the user is asked to supply computer name and join a domain or workgroup.
segment.target: SkipDomainMembership – This rule, when combined with the SkipComputerName rule, prevents the Computer Details page from being displayed, where the user is asked to supply computer name and join a domain or workgroup.

segment.source: JoinDomain – This rule instructs the Windows Deployment Wizard to have the computer join the specified domain using the specified credentials.
segment.target: JoinDomain – This rule instructs the Windows Deployment Wizard to have the computer join the specified domain using the specified credentials.

segment.source: DomainAdmin – This rule specifies the username for the domain join operation.
segment.target: DomainAdmin – This rule specifies the username for the domain join operation.

segment.source: DomainAdminDomain – This rule specifies the domain for the username for the domain join operation.
segment.target: DomainAdminDomain – This rule specifies the domain for the username for the domain join operation.

segment.source: DomainAdminPassword – This rule specifies the password for the username for the domain join operation.
segment.target: DomainAdminPassword – This rule specifies the password for the username for the domain join operation.

segment.source: SkipLocaleSelection – This rule, along with the SkipTimeZone rule, prevents the Locale and Time page from being displayed.
segment.target: SkipLocaleSelection – This rule, along with the SkipTimeZone rule, prevents the Locale and Time page from being displayed.

segment.source: KeyboardLocale – This rule is used to specify the keyboard layout for the deployed Windows environment.
segment.target: KeyboardLocale – This rule is used to specify the keyboard layout for the deployed Windows environment.

segment.source: UserLocale – This rule is used to specify the geographical locale for the deployed Windows environment.
segment.target: UserLocale – This rule is used to specify the geographical locale for the deployed Windows environment.

segment.source: UILanguage – This rule is used to specify the language to be used in the deployed Windows environment.
segment.target: UILanguage – This rule is used to specify the language to be used in the deployed Windows environment.

segment.source: SkipTimeZone – This rule, along with the SkipLocaleSelection rule, prevents the Locale and Time page from being displayed.
segment.target: SkipTimeZone – This rule, along with the SkipLocaleSelection rule, prevents the Locale and Time page from being displayed.

segment.source: TimeZoneName – This rule is used to specify the time zone for the deployed Windows environment.
segment.target: TimeZoneName – This rule is used to specify the time zone for the deployed Windows environment.

segment.source: UserID – This rule is used to supply the username under which the MDT actions and task sequence steps are performed.
segment.target: UserID – This rule is used to supply the username under which the MDT actions and task sequence steps are performed.

segment.source: UserDomain – This rule is used to supply the domain for the username under which the MDT actions and task sequence steps are performed.
segment.target: UserDomain – This rule is used to supply the domain for the username under which the MDT actions and task sequence steps are performed.

segment.source: UserPassword – This rule is used to supply the password for the username under which the MDT actions and task sequence steps are performed.
segment.target: UserPassword – This rule is used to supply the password for the username under which the MDT actions and task sequence steps are performed.

segment.source: SkipSummary – This rule prevents the Summary page from being displayed before the task sequence is run, where the user is prompted to confirm the selections before beginning the task sequence.
segment.target: SkipSummary – This rule prevents the Summary page from being displayed before the task sequence is run, where the user is prompted to confirm the selections before beginning the task sequence.

segment.source: SkipFinalSummary – This rule prevents the Summary page from being displayed when the task sequence has completed.
segment.target: SkipFinalSummary – This rule prevents the Summary page from being displayed when the task sequence has completed.

segment.source: FinishAction – This rule specifies whether to log out, reboot, or shut down the device after the task sequence has completed.
segment.target: FinishAction – This rule specifies whether to log out, reboot, or shut down the device after the task sequence has completed.

segment.source: You can read about all of the possible deployment share and boot media rules in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit Reference.
segment.target: You can read about all of the possible deployment share and boot media rules in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit Reference.

segment.source: Update and import updated MDT boot media
segment.target: Update and import updated MDT boot media

segment.source: The process to update MDT boot media with these new rules and changes to the deployment share is very similar to the process to generate boot media from scratch.
segment.target: The process to update MDT boot media with these new rules and changes to the deployment share is very similar to the process to generate boot media from scratch.

segment.source: To update the MDT boot media, follow these steps:
segment.target: To update the MDT boot media, follow these steps:

segment.source: Right-click the deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click Update Deployment Share to start the Update Deployment Share Wizard.
segment.target: Right-click the deployment share in the Deployment Workbench, and then click Update Deployment Share to start the Update Deployment Share Wizard.

segment.source: The Update Deployment Share Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:
segment.target: The Update Deployment Share Wizard displays a series of steps, as follows:

segment.source: Options – Choose between the Completely Regenerate the Boot Images or Optimize the Boot Image Updating Process options.
segment.target: Options – Choose between the Completely Regenerate the Boot Images or Optimize the Boot Image Updating Process options.

segment.source: Completely regenerating the boot images will take more time, but produces boot media that is not fragmented and does not contain out of date components.
segment.target: Completely regenerating the boot images will take more time, but produces boot media that is not fragmented and does not contain out of date components.

segment.source: Optimizing the boot image updating process will proceed more quickly, but may result in longer load times when booting via PXE.
segment.target: Optimizing the boot image updating process will proceed more quickly, but may result in longer load times when booting via PXE.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Summary – Review the specified options on this page before you click Next to begin the update of boot images.
segment.target: Summary – Review the specified options on this page before you click Next to begin the update of boot images.

segment.source: Progress – While the boot images are being updated a progress bar is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Progress – While the boot images are being updated a progress bar is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Confirmation – When the boot images have been updated, the success of the process is displayed on this page.
segment.target: Confirmation – When the boot images have been updated, the success of the process is displayed on this page.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete the Update Deployment Share Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete the Update Deployment Share Wizard.

segment.source: To import the updated MDT boot media into WDS for PXE boot, follow these steps:
segment.target: To import the updated MDT boot media into WDS for PXE boot, follow these steps:

segment.source: Open Windows Deployment Services from the Start menu or Start screen.
segment.target: Open Windows Deployment Services from the Start menu or Start screen.

segment.source: Expand Servers and your deployment server.
segment.target: Expand Servers and your deployment server.

segment.source: Click the Boot Images folder.
segment.target: Click the Boot Images folder.

segment.source: Right-click the existing MDT boot image, and then click Replace Image to open the Replace Boot Image Wizard.
segment.target: Right-click the existing MDT boot image, and then click Replace Image to open the Replace Boot Image Wizard.

segment.source: Replace the previously imported MDT boot image with the updated version by using these steps in the Replace Boot Image Wizard:
segment.target: Replace the previously imported MDT boot image with the updated version by using these steps in the Replace Boot Image Wizard:

segment.source: Image File – Click Browse and navigate to the Boot folder in your deployment share, click LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, and then click Open.
segment.target: Image File – Click Browse and navigate to the Boot folder in your deployment share, click LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, and then click Open.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Available Images – Only one image should be listed and selected LiteTouch Windows PE (x86), click Next.
segment.target: Available Images – Only one image should be listed and selected LiteTouch Windows PE (x86), click Next.

segment.source: Image Metadata – Enter a name and description for the MDT boot media, or click Next to accept the default options.
segment.target: Image Metadata – Enter a name and description for the MDT boot media, or click Next to accept the default options.

segment.source: Summary – Review your selections for importing a boot image into WDS, and then click Next.
segment.target: Summary – Review your selections for importing a boot image into WDS, and then click Next.

segment.source: Task Progress – A progress bar is displayed as the selected image file is copied into the WDS remote installation folder.
segment.target: Task Progress – A progress bar is displayed as the selected image file is copied into the WDS remote installation folder.

segment.source: Click Finish when the task is complete to close the Replace Boot Image Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish when the task is complete to close the Replace Boot Image Wizard.

segment.source: Right-click the Boot Images folder, and then click Add Image to open the Add Image Wizard.
segment.target: Right-click the Boot Images folder, and then click Add Image to open the Add Image Wizard.

segment.source: Add the new 64-bit boot image for 64-bit UEFI device compatibility with the Add Image Wizard , as follows:
segment.target: Add the new 64-bit boot image for 64-bit UEFI device compatibility with the Add Image Wizard , as follows:

segment.source: Image File – Click Browse and navigate to the Boot folder in your deployment share, select LiteTouchPE_x64.wim, and then click Open.
segment.target: Image File – Click Browse and navigate to the Boot folder in your deployment share, select LiteTouchPE_x64.wim, and then click Open.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Image Metadata – Enter a name and description for the MDT boot media, or click Next to accept the default options.
segment.target: Image Metadata – Enter a name and description for the MDT boot media, or click Next to accept the default options.

segment.source: Summary – Review your selections to import a boot image into WDS, and then click Next.
segment.target: Summary – Review your selections to import a boot image into WDS, and then click Next.

segment.source: Task Progress – A progress bar is displayed as the selected image file is copied into the WDS remote installation folder.
segment.target: Task Progress – A progress bar is displayed as the selected image file is copied into the WDS remote installation folder.

segment.source: Click Finish when the task is complete to close the Add Image Wizard.
segment.target: Click Finish when the task is complete to close the Add Image Wizard.

segment.source: Note:Although it is a best practice to replace and update the boot images in WDS whenever the MDT deployment share is updated, for deployment to Surface devices the 32-bit boot image, LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, is not required.
segment.target: Note:Although it is a best practice to replace and update the boot images in WDS whenever the MDT deployment share is updated, for deployment to Surface devices the 32-bit boot image, LiteTouchPE_x86.wim, is not required.

segment.source: Only the 64-bit boot image is required for 64-bit UEFI devices.
segment.target: Only the 64-bit boot image is required for 64-bit UEFI devices.

segment.source: Deploy Windows to Surface
segment.target: Deploy Windows to Surface

segment.source: With all of the automation provided by the deployment share rules and task sequence, performing the deployment on each Surface device becomes as easy as a single touch.
segment.target: With all of the automation provided by the deployment share rules and task sequence, performing the deployment on each Surface device becomes as easy as a single touch.

segment.source: Note:For the deployment to require only a single touch, the Surface devices must be connected to a keyboard, connected to the network with a Microsoft Surface USB Ethernet Adapter or Surface Dock, and configured with PXE boot as the first boot option, as shown in Figure 25.
segment.target: Note:For the deployment to require only a single touch, the Surface devices must be connected to a keyboard, connected to the network with a Microsoft Surface USB Ethernet Adapter or Surface Dock, and configured with PXE boot as the first boot option, as shown in Figure 25.

segment.source: Set boot priority for PXE boot
segment.target: Set boot priority for PXE boot

segment.source: Figure 25.
segment.target: Figure 25.

segment.source: Setting boot priority for PXE boot
segment.target: Setting boot priority for PXE boot

segment.source: On a properly configured Surface device, simply turn on the device and press Enter when you are prompted to boot from the network.
segment.target: On a properly configured Surface device, simply turn on the device and press Enter when you are prompted to boot from the network.

segment.source: The fully automated MDT deployment process will then take over and perform the following tasks:
segment.target: The fully automated MDT deployment process will then take over and perform the following tasks:

segment.source: The MDT boot media will be loaded to your Surface device via the network
segment.target: The MDT boot media will be loaded to your Surface device via the network

segment.source: The MDT boot media will use the provided credentials and rules to connect to the MDT deployment share
segment.target: The MDT boot media will use the provided credentials and rules to connect to the MDT deployment share

segment.source: The task sequence and drivers will be automatically selected for your device via make and model information
segment.target: The task sequence and drivers will be automatically selected for your device via make and model information

segment.source: The task sequence will deploy your updated Windows 10 image to the device complete with the selected drivers
segment.target: The task sequence will deploy your updated Windows 10 image to the device complete with the selected drivers

segment.source: The task sequence will join your device to the domain
segment.target: The task sequence will join your device to the domain

segment.source: The task sequence will install the applications you specified, Microsoft Office and Surface app
segment.target: The task sequence will install the applications you specified, Microsoft Office and Surface app

segment.source: Windows Update will run, installing any new Windows Updates or updates for installed applications, like Microsoft Office
segment.target: Windows Update will run, installing any new Windows Updates or updates for installed applications, like Microsoft Office

segment.source: The task sequence will complete silently and log out of the device
segment.target: The task sequence will complete silently and log out of the device

segment.source: Note:For Surface devices not configured to boot to the network as the first boot option, you can hold Volume Down and press Power to boot the system immediately to a USB or network device.
segment.target: Note:For Surface devices not configured to boot to the network as the first boot option, you can hold Volume Down and press Power to boot the system immediately to a USB or network device.

segment.source: The resulting configuration is a Surface device that is logged out and ready for an end user to enter their credentials, log on, and get right to work.
segment.target: The resulting configuration is a Surface device that is logged out and ready for an end user to enter their credentials, log on, and get right to work.

segment.source: The applications and drivers they need are already installed and up to date.
segment.target: The applications and drivers they need are already installed and up to date.
